If you guys are having problems after entering the serial (The serials work but then it asks you for another serial on next launch), make a firewall rule for "C:\Program Files\Common Files\Adobe\OOBE\PDApp\core\PDApp.exe" and deny it access on any network.
It solved the problem for me.

Those who have a problem:  Download CS5.5 directly from Adobe.  When download is complete, shut off your anti-virus and download here as the Adobe download is long.  When this download is done, create your serial in the keygen.  The reason you shut your anti-virus is that the keygen will seem like a Trojan and will be removed.  IT IS NOT A TROJAN.  Anyway, once you enter in the serial, you will get your green check and all will be fine.  Enjoy.  Thanks scene4all!

@sweetvim,

I just ran this successfully on Win 7 x64, so I'll try to explain the process that worked for me, and I'll throw in some background info that might help you (and anyone else reading this) resolve your issues.

First of all, let me explain the setup process on a high level (because I think you might be over-complicating things).

1.  You go to Adobe, get the trial download, and proceed with the normal installation process.

2.  After you've downloaded the necessary shit (it's like 6 gigs or something), the installer asks for a serial number (or to indicate that you're only doing a 30 day trial--but we don't want this option, we want to give it a serial number). This is where you run the keygen and paste in the serial number it generates for you. The green check indicates that it's a valid number sequence--but it doesn't know whether or not that serial number has been used (that check is done during activation...which we will prevent from happening).

3.  After your selected programs are installed, you have yourself a fully-functional CS5.5 Master Edition...but as soon as you open one of the programs, it's going to connect to Adobe's activation server and verify your serial number. Then you're fucked. So you have to make sure Adobe's activation server is unreachable before you open any of your new programs.

4a.  The first method to block activation is to configure your computer's firewall so that it doesn't let Adobe make outbound connections. I personally didn't use this method, but it could work.

4b.  The second method to block activation is to edit the Windows hosts file so that Adobe thinks it's connecting to the activation server, but really it's connecting to your own computer--which is harmless. This is the method I used, and it's the method explained in this torrent's install.txt file. (When you run disable_activation.cmd, it edits the hosts file for you.)

4c.  The third method to block activation is to disconnect your computer from the internet. Not the most realistic method, but it is certainly the most foolproof. The first 2 methods are meant to block only Adobe's activation servers while keeping everything else connected.

5.  As long as Adobe can't reach it's activation server, your programs should continue to work like a fully licensed installation.

(...continued from previous comment)

Now that we have that out of the way, let me explain a couple of gotchas/bugs that you should be aware of, especially if you are using the 4b method.



-- To edit the Windows hosts file, you need administrator privileges. Therefore, to run disable_activation.cmd successfully, you need to run it as an administrator. To do this, right-click on it and select "Run as administrator".

-- TIP: On Windows 7, the hosts file is located at C:WindowsSystem32driversetchosts

-- When I ran disable_activation.cmd, it DID NOT WORK properly, due to a minor bug/typo. Thankfully I caught it before opening any Adobe programs. The reason I was able to catch the error is because I opened the hosts file in Notepad and manually inspected it before and after running disable_activation.cmd. Here is my before/after snapshot:



BEFORE:

# several lines of comments

127.0.0.1       localhost127.0.0.1



AFTER (notice the missing line break between "localhost" and "127.0.0.1"):

# several lines of comments

127.0.0.1       localhost127.0.0.1                   activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1                   practivate.adobe.com



AFTER (fixed):

# several lines of comments

127.0.0.1       localhost
127.0.0.1       activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1       practivate.adobe.com



-- To edit the hosts file manually, you need to run Notepad with admin privileges--otherwise it won't save your changes. To accomplish this, click the Start Menu icon, type "Notepad" into the search box, right-click on the Notepad search result that appears, and select "Run as administrator". If UAC is enabled, it will ask to proceed--click yes. Once Notepad is open, open the hosts file, make changes if needed, and save. Again, that file is located at:

C:WindowsSystem32driversetchosts

(...continuing from previous comment)

==========
CORRECTIONS
==========



BEFORE:

 # several lines of comments

 127.0.0.1 localhost



Hosts file location (TPB strips out backslashes, so trying slashes here instead):

C:/Windows/System32/drivers/etc/hosts

(...continued from previous comment)

Now, on to your questions...



Q:  Should I update?

A:  It is possible that Adobe will one day pull their head out of their ass and figure out how to patch this loophole. When they do, the only way to get that patch onto your computer is through an update. Therefore, every time you allow Adobe to update your software, you should be prepared to immediately roll back those changes if necessary. In other words, do a full backup before you update. After the update, check to make sure everything still works. (Or another strategy might be to wait a few weeks and check forums to see if anyone is bitching about the latest update killing their software.)



Q:  Same with the sign-in, is that allowed or will it cause "issues" (i.e. Adobe Story and a few others ask for sign in to use program)?

A:  I don't know. Just to be safe/paranoid, I created a new email account specifically for this purpose. It works perfectly, as far as I can tell.



Q:  Acrobat keeps failing says need re-install, so I am trying to do that now (internet off and will go through activation run again). Flashbuilder, same issue fails to load says stops working Windows will close and let me know when resolution is found, so reinstalled both but not testing until i get answers to all these

A:  Using method 4b, I didn't experience any of these issues. And judging by your other comment, it looks like you got this resolved. 



Q:  Encore error and closes "Adobe Encore CS5.1 cannot run in non-royalty serialized mode. The application needs to be serialized with a royalty bearing serial number." How do I resolve?

A:  I don't have this issue. Try editing your hosts file as explained above. It could be related to your keygen serials not working and the fact that you got your serial from somewhere else? Worst case...uninstall, reinstall with a different serial, edit hosts file, and you should be good to go.



Q:  Illustrator & InDesign both do the same thing; they open and then immediately close. I finally caught the error message which states, " is not properly licensed and will now quit."

A:  Again, I didn't experience this problem, so I'm not much help here. But my advice from previous question applies here too.

(...continued from previous comment)

==============
SIDE NOTE
==============



If anyone is wondering why I just spent over an hour typing up this detailed explanation of how to crack Adobe Creative Suite 5.5 Master Collection, then here's your answer:

I paid over $1K for CS4 Master Collection (I was a student at the time). I'm not rich by any means, so this purchase was a huge decision--but ultimately, I decided it was worth it because I didn't want to deal with the risks that come with cracked software.

Since then, I have replaced/reformatted my hard drive and re-installed CS4 two different times (mind you, the installation is from the boxed set of DVDs that I paid full price for and still physically have in my possession). Unbeknownst to me, each time I re-installed the software, Adobe's activation server was tracking the number of installations and only allows a max of 2 installations. In order to install it a 3rd time, I was instructed to open the software on my "other 2 computers" and initiate the deactivation process.

Needless to say, it's kind of difficult to open my first 2 installations considering the fact that #1 was on a busted hard drive and #2 was overwritten when I reformatted. Consequently, Adobe refused to let me use my $1K software!

I searched adobe.com and found a number to call to speak to someone about activating my software. An automated voice system answers, tells me to hold for the next available associate, and then tells me the expected waiting time is "more than 2 hours"!

It was at that point that I began researching how to crack Adobe's license/activation system. And the funny thing is...it took less than 2 hours.

So Adobe...if you're reading this: You need to get your shit together. For a retail price of $2,599...you better make sure your fuckin' software doesn't lock out paying customers. And if it does, you better make DAMN sure those paying customers don't have to wait more than 5 minutes to be let back in.

You brought this on yourselves, you fuckin' greedy pigs. You can eat my asshole for over two hours.
